title: Natural Disaster Doc Series  Violent Earth with Liev Schreiber  Trailer
message:
Natural Disaster Doc Series 'Violent Earth with Liev Schreiber' Trailer"When Mother Nature speaks – listen."
Max has posted the trailer for a documentary series called Violent Earth with Liev Schreiber, an "in-depth examination into our natural world and its changing climate."
Violent Earth with Liev Schreiber explores the unbelievable science behind epic natural disasters.
Schreiber described Violent Earth as a "cautionary tale" about the increased frequency of violent storms, but he sees reason for hope in our growing understanding of them.
Violent Earth with Liev Schreiber is a series is produced by Jing Feng and John Wasley, and executive produced by Nancy Duffy, Senior Vice President, Program Development at CNN.

title: A tropical wave has a chance of becoming a storm , but will it affect Panama City Beach ?
message:
A tropical wave has a chance of becoming a storm, but will it affect Panama City Beach?
The National Hurricane Center is giving a low chance — 20% — for development over the next 48 hours.
If sustained winds reach 39 mph, it could become Tropical Storm Debby, the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.
Tropical cyclone is the generic term that covers all tropical systems, including tropical depression, tropical storm and hurricane.
The striped areas on a tropical outlook map indicate "areas where a tropical cyclone — which could be a tropical depression, tropical storm or hurricane — could develop," said National Hurricane Center Deputy Director Jamie Rhome.

title: August Weather Headlines
message:
HARRISONBURG, Va. (WHSV) - As July turns into August, the final month of summer has officially begun, but will the weather look any different from the last few dry months?
With late summer knocking on the doorsteps, tropical systems will start to become more common by the end of the month.
Activity historically starts to climb late month into September.
However, tropical systems become much more common from late August through October.
These types of systems often produce widespread, soaking rainfall, and is likely the sole way the region will break the drought.

title: Hanahan mayor warns and advises residents ahead of hurricane season peak
message:
Hanahan Mayor Christie Rainwater penned a letter to residents Tuesday acknowledging community concerns about flooding and hurricane preparedness, while also advising residents on how to best stay safe during a storm.
Rainwater also shared that the city has been attempting to obtain flood insurance premium discounts for residents via the National Flood Insurance Program's (NFIP) Community Rating System.
Points are then used to reduce flood insurance premiums for policyholders.
The Hanahan Mayor claimed that residents now receive a 20 percent discount on their flood insurance premiums due to participation in the Community Rating System.
The letter comes as hurricane season reaches its peak, prompting many Lowcountry governments and emergency organizations to increase preparations for a major storm.

title: Florida on alert for tropical downpours as models shift disturbance to Gulf of Mexico
message:
For several days, model forecasts consistently indicated that the tropical wave, now known as Invest 97L, would likely move into the Atlantic.
However, by Thursday, the models have generally agreed that it will now track into the Gulf of Mexico and is expected to become tropical storm Debby.
While the forecast intensity is still uncertain, we may see a tropical depression, tropical storm or potentially a hurricane.
As of 2 p.m. the tropical wave is producing disorganized showers and thunderstorms over Hispaniola, Puerto Rico, the southeastern Bahamas, and in the southwestern Atlantic and northeastern Caribbean Sea.
As of Thursday morning, the NHC says the tropical wave has a medium (70%) chance for development over the next seven days.

title: Hurricane preparedness : Tropical terms to get familiar with
message:
Tropical Cyclone: Any tropical area of low pressure found anywhere around the world.
Potential Tropical Cyclone: Designated by the National Hurricane Center when a disturbance that has not yet met all of the meteorological characteristics to become tropical but has the strong potential to become one.
The disturbance will receive this designation when it has a strong chance to bring tropical storm or hurricane conditions to land within 48 hours.
Tropical Outlook: Issued by the National Hurricane Center to highlight an area of disturbed weather that has a chance to develop into a tropical depression, storm or hurricane.
Tropical Advisory: Issued when a tropical depression develops.

title: Tropical Storm Carlotta strengthens over Pacific Ocean as it moves away from Mexico – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
MIAMI (AP) — Tropical Storm Carlotta is growing stronger over the Pacific Ocean as it moves away from Mexico and could become a hurricane by Thursday evening, forecasters said.
The National Hurricane Center in Miami said Thursday morning that Carlotta’s maximum sustained winds had grown to 60 mph (95 kph).
The system was centered about 345 miles (630 kilometers) southwest of Manzanilla, Mexico, moving northwest at 12 mph (19 kph).
Swells generated by the storm will likely cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions through the weekend along Mexico’s west-central mainland coast and the southern Baja California peninsula, the hurricane center warned.

title: Forecasters predict Tropical Storm Carlotta to grow into hurricane
message:
Tropical Storm Carlotta off the western coast of Mexico is expected to grow into a hurricane, forecasters said.
Photo courtesy of NOAAAug. 1 (UPI) -- The National Hurricane Center said Thursday that Pacific Ocean Tropical Storm Carlotta is expected to become a hurricane late Thursday or Friday.
"This motion is expected to continue [Thursday], followed by a turn toward the west on Friday and a continued westward motion through the weekend," the National Hurricane Center said.
"Strengthening is forecast during the next couple of days and Carlotta is expected to become a hurricane today or [Friday]."

title: State Affairs committee looks into power outages after Hurricane Beryl
message:
Hurricane Beryl is gone and most of the power line repair work is done in Houston.
On Wednesday, members of the House State Affairs Committee brought back the CEO of CenterPoint Energy, Jason Wells, who issued another apology for how the power provider responded to the power outage.
Committee members expressed their frustration with the answers they've been getting, especially regarding how power poles are maintained.
Those trees were not part of the CenterPoint vegetation reduction plan.
Wells told the committee more than 40 policy changes have been made, or are in the process of being implemented.

title: Severe Storms in the Southeast US Leave 1 Dead and Cause Widespread Power Outages
message:
CANTON, Ga.—A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
Wednesday’s remaining outages were most concentrated around the town of Ellijay in the north Georgia mountains.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city’s downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.

message:

The Aftermath of the Severe Thunderstorm in Missoula, Montana - July 2024 The National Weather Service cited 80 mph winds at the Missoula Montana Airport and over 100 mph winds at the apex of Mount Sentinel.

title: Officials declare California wildfires have burned 5 times more area this year alone :  We are not just in a fire season , we are in a fire year
message:
Officials declare California wildfires have burned 5 times more area this year alone: 'We are not just in a fire season, we are in a fire year'Wildfires in California burned more than 300,000 acres through the third week of July.
It is still relatively early in California's wildfire season, but it is unfortunately already off to a roaring start.
Through the third week of July, the number of acres burned had nearly tripled the average of the past five years, according to Cal Fire.
There have been more than 4,000 wildland fires and over 2,500 structural fires in California so far.

title: Tropical wave changes direction . Is SC still in its path ? | Hurricane Wire
message:
The system is a tropical wave, and it was predicted to follow a northwesterly course when it appeared on a National Weather Service map late last week.
Had the system continued to follow that line, it could have been sitting off the South Carolina coast with a chance of developing into a tropical cyclone.
The predicted track has now shifted west, taking South Carolina out of its direct path for the time being.
Chances that the wave will develop into a more serious tropical cyclone over the next two days are pegged at 20 percent.
A tropical wave is an elongated area of relatively low pressure that moves east to west across the tropics.

title: Charleston County prepares for severe storms with emergency exercise
message:
NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCSC) - Multiple agencies participated in Charleston County’s full-scale exercise to simulate a hurricane and determine the best response strategies.
The Charleston County emergency management team, plus more than 110 people from law enforcement, EMS and public works participated in an emergency exercise Wednesday at the Emergency Operations Center.
Each year, county officials look at ways to not only add to their emergency plan but also refine it to ensure its effectiveness.
Interim Director for Emergency Management for Charleston County Ben Webster explains how these exercises test their abilities.
“It gets everyone in the same room, it gets everybody communicating, making sure that plan works, making sure that communication structure works and making sure that command structure works,” Webster said.

title: Invest 97L Could Pose Threat To Florida | FM 96 . 9 The Game
message:
(Miami, FL) -- Forecasters are tracking a large tropical wave as it gets closer to Florida.
The latest update from the National Hurricane Center shows that the system is located near the Lesser Antilles, creating disorganized showers and thunderstorms.
There is a 60-percent chance the storm will develop into a tropical depression in the next week as it travels toward the Bahamas and most of Florida.
The state could start to see impacts from the system this weekend and into early next week.
State emergency management officials are urging residents to make sure they have a plan in place before a disaster hits.

title: Is New Jersey suffering quake envy ?
message:
New Jersey comes with so many disappointments you’d think we’d be immune to them.
It’s when there’s a quake big enough to be felt yet I don’t feel it.
As Dan Alexander reported there was yet another aftershock to the April earthquake whose epicenter was in Hunterdon County.
It reminds me of the one in August 2011 when a 5.9 quake hit in Virginia and was felt throughout New Jersey and much of the Northeast.
Suddenly half the people in the building were excitedly running around asking others if “they felt it.” The rest of us were asking, “Felt what?”It was a matter of what part of the building you were in.

title: IOP first responders take part in full - scale exercise to prepare for hurricanes
message:
ISLE OF PALMS, S.C. (WCBD) – First responders on the Isle of Palms put their hurricane response skills to the test on Wednesday during a full-scale exercise involving an imaginary storm.
IOP police officers busted through the doors of a room inside of the resort, which jumpstarted the exercise.
First responders quickly tended to the four volunteers pretending to be victims who sustained injuries amid the chaos.
After a few minutes, the helicopter landed, Maynard was loaded inside, and they were back in the air again, marking the end of the exercise.
The simulation was part of a larger multi-day exercise conducted by the Charleston County Emergency Management Department.

title: BC Issues Flood Warning , Watches After Landslide Blocks River , Forces Evacuations
message:
A massive amount of debris from a landslide damming the Chilcotin River in British Columbia’s central Interior could give way within the next 24 to 48 hours.
Wagner told a news briefing that the riverbed below the slide is dry, and officials aren’t certain about the potential downstream impacts when the dam is breached.
But she says it’s clear there would be “a mass of water” coming down the Chilcotin, which flows south into the Fraser River.
Evacuation orders span 107 square kilometres along the Chilcotin, with the regional officials saying the slide poses an “immediate danger to life and safety.”The district says 60 properties are covered by the orders, including 12 homes with an estimated 13 residents.
Wagner says the slide is “massive,” with material piled 30 metres high and stretching 600 metres in length, completely blocking the flow of the Chilcotin.

title: B . C . issues flood warning , watches after landslide blocks river , forces evacuations – Winnipeg Free Press
message:

That variable timing optimizes cylinder firing in all gears, providing torque for towing but also reliable horsepower throughout the rpm range.
As the HEMI has aged, emissions standards have gotten stricter, and for the 2024 model year, this engine was phased out.
The Ram 1500 replaced it with the Hurricane, a new, smaller engine.
The Hurricane engine has six cylinders and two turbochargers — each turbocharger boosting three cylinders.

title: Technically at war , South Korea offers flood relief to North Korea
message:
South Korea is ready to provide North Korea with relief supplies for damage caused by recent heavy rainfall, South Korea’s Red Cross said on Thursday, marking a rare outreach under the administration of President Yoon Suk Yeol to its neighbour.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un personally inspected the flooded areas and expressed grave concern over the damage, state media said on Monday.
There is a possibility of “significant human casualties” in North Korea, a Unification Ministry official said on Thursday.
North Korea has cut off all lines of official communication with the South.
More rain was forecast for Sinuiju on Thursday and early Friday, according to South Korea’s weather agency.

title: Loudoun County farmers can apply for emergency drought aid
message:
LOUDOUN COUNTY, Va. (DC News Now) — Farmers in Loudoun County are eligible for emergency loan assistance from the federal government due to the drought during this year’s growing season.
U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Thomas Vilsack declared Loudoun and 14 other Virginia counties as “primary natural disaster areas,” allowing the Farm Service Agency (FSA) to offer emergency loans and other assistance to farmers impacted by the drought.
Farmers have eight months to apply for the loans.
Farmers in Loudoun County specifically can also receive support through the Loudoun County Department of Economic Development and Virginia Cooperative Extension.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to DC News Now | Washington, DC.

title: Banff , Lake Louise put out call for visitors amid Jasper National Park wildfire closure

Send this page to someone via emailTourism officials in Banff and Lake Louise, Alta., are reminding visitors that those mountain towns are open for business as Jasper National Park remains closed due to wildfires.

“We understand that the recent wildfire in Jasper has raised concerns among some travellers,” said Leslie Bruce, president and CEO of Banff and Lake Louise Tourism.

Jasper National Park was evacuated on July 22 as wildfires encroached on the community.

title: National Hurricane Center tracking possible tropical storm formation near Bahamas , Florida – ICSF
message:
A​ disturbance in the Atlantic continues to be watched for possible formation into a tropical storm, but there are multiple scenarios in play when it comes to the track of this system as it nears the Bahamas and the southeastern United States by this weekend.
The tropical wave that might eventually grow into a tropical depression or storm is located over the Leeward Islands, or near the “X” in the graphic below, according to the National Hurricane Center.
C​omputer models suggest wind shear may be relatively light, and there’s plenty of warm ocean water ahead of this system to fuel its development near the Bahamas or the Gulf of Mexico.
However, this rather large tropical disturbance will likely have to interact with land along the way, particularly Hispaniola and Cuba, but also possibly Florida.
So, it may take some time for one area of thunderstorms to persist over water, lower surface pressure and begin the process of developing a tropical depression, if that happens at all.

title: Report : CenterPoint Plans To Pass Beryl - Related Expenses Onto Customers
message:
CenterPoint Energy Inc. plans to pass on to their customers an estimated $2 billion in costs related to the powerful storm that ravaged Houston and the surrounding area.
During an earnings call Tuesday (July 30), Chief Financial Officer Christopher Foster told investors and analysts the company will issue bonds to recover expenses related to the storm.
Beryl drenched Houston with a summer’s worth of rain and brought 75 mph winds with gusts even higher.
The Beryl-related death toll climbed to more than 20 people in Texas, many of which are due to heat-related illnesses.
Nearly half of the deaths in Harris County have been attributed to heat exposure, according to the Harris County Institute of Forensic Sciences.

title: CenterPoint CEO Jason Wells repeats need for rate hike
message:
(Photo by Danielle Villasana/Getty Images) Danielle Villasana/Getty ImagesEmbattled CenterPoint Energy CEO Jason Wells reiterated his company's plan to raise rates for Houston customers, insisting the money is needed to "make significant investments in our infrastructure."
"The company is on negative outlook with the credit rating agencies," Wells said, according to Houston Public Media.
CenterPoint reported income of $228 million for the quarter ending June 30, up from $118 million the previous year.
Advertisement Article continues below this adWells also discussed the company's plans to replace the wooden poles that failed during Beryl, noting that less than half a percent of the wooden poles failed.
Wells said the utility plans to replace just 1,000 wooden poles with newer, composite ones by the end of the year.

title: I Saw Twisters And Loved It But This One Aspect Really Impacted Me
message:
Twisters is a movie I never planned to watch, at least in the theater.
Twisters could have simply been a fun movie about chasing tornadoes and tornado wrangling.
The film doesn’t really take a stand and go "maybe if people stopped doing this, then maybe there would be fewer tornadoes."
Twisters potential impact may justify its existence and maybe create a demand for more standalone sequels to '90s movies.
Could you hold on to bars in a pool and really protect yourself from flying away during a storm??

title: Wildfires rage in Balkans and Greece
message:
ANTONIO BRONIC/REUTERSFierce wildfires, propelled by strong winds, ravaged areas of Greece and the Balkans on Tuesday, destroying forests and homes and forcing the evacuation of an Albanian resort town, local officials reported.
The area has experienced higher-than-normal temperatures and arid conditions throughout the previous month, establishing perfect circumstances for the outbreak of wildfires, according to scientists.
In recent years, Greece has experienced an increase in wildfire occurrences during progressively hotter and drier summers, a trend that scientists attribute to climate change.
The country has been grappling with hundreds of wildfires since May, coinciding with its record-breaking hottest June and longest-ever heatwave.
Europe is experiencing the most rapid warming of any continent globally, with Greece among nations most severely impacted by the consequences of anthropogenic climate change, reported Euronews.
